prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: The estimated source fluxes at 230 GHz are 1-10 mJy, typically 3-5 mJy, and with a sensitivity per pointing of 0.08 mJy (continuum) we achieve SNRs of at least 10 for solid detections and up to > 100 for imaging with a resolution of 0.5" corresponding to 4 kpc at z ~ 3. To be sure not to resolve out flux of the galaxies the Largest Angular Scale is set to 5". The sensitivity can be achieved as there are no dynamic range limitations.
Imaging: Even snapshots provide excellent imaging and will give useful hints on the structure/morphology one can expect to be present in high-z star-bursting galaxies. One would expect this for the brighter, presumably larger galaxies in the sample. For sources at the weaker end of the flux distribution a point source detection will be adequate.
Correlator setup: We use a standard band 6 continuum set-up in TDM mode with 7.5 GHz bandwidth. Weighing the trade-offs between band 6 and 7, the two times larger beam than band 7 for more serendipitous detections in our overdense (proto-)cluster fields and that observing in average conditions can be done easily are important arguments.
Calibration: Standard observatory calibration will be used.
There are no special requirements on Bandpass accuracy, Scheduling/time constraints, Data rate (< 6MB/s) or any other observing aspect.
The 5-10 pointings per cluster source (Science Goal) can be achieved in one single execution per each of the 4 SBs with a good science time to (calibration-/)overhead ratio. Our total sample of 30, or more detectable, galaxies in (proto-)cluster environments can be used for statistical statements regarding dust mass and morphology distributions.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Fossil evidence in the nearby Universe suggests that massive galaxy clusters formed most of their stellar mass in very short, vigorous bursts of star-formation resulting in very bright (L_FIR of-order 10^14 Lsun), high-z Mpc environs which are hitherto unobserved. Through a unique synergy of the Planck all-sky survey and Herschel/SPIRE photometry we have selected a sample of the 230 brightest high-z Mpc environs on the FIR/sub-mm sky. Most are overdensities of red SPIRE sources with the typical colors of bona-fide "Herschel" high-z galaxies. We request ALMA 12-m-array 0.5" resolution dust imaging in Band 6 of 4 sources to uniquely associate the dust emission with individual galaxies in the associated strong galaxy over-densities. This will also enable us to elucidate the nature of SPIRE "blobs" without obvious stellar counterpart. Are these the vestiges of extended gas and dust that contributed to fueling the extraordinary star-formation activity through which the most massive galaxy clusters where shaped? Our program illustrates the power of ALMA, combining high sensitivity and high spatial resolution, on truly outstanding objects in the early universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
